article.title: Evidence of pre-processing and a dependence on dynamical state for low-mass satellite galaxies

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 shows the halo mass distribution for galaxies in the unmatched Gaussian and non-Gaussian samples. What can be inferred from this figure?
choices: Gaussian groups are exclusively found at high halo masses.
Non-Gaussian groups are generally less massive than Gaussian groups.
The sample size is heavily biased towards identifying non-Gaussian groups at low halo masses.
The distribution of halo masses is identical for both Gaussian and non-Gaussian groups.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 showcases the distribution of stellar mass, redshift, and host halo mass for galaxies in different matched samples. What is the primary reason for matching these samples?
choices: To showcase the diverse properties of galaxies in different environments.
To highlight the similarities between galaxies in Gaussian and non-Gaussian groups.
To eliminate biases caused by variations in stellar mass, redshift, and halo mass when studying group dynamics.
To illustrate the effectiveness of the matching algorithm used in the study.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 investigates star-forming and disc fractions of galaxies at large radii. What key observation can be made from this figure regarding the impact of group dynamics?
choices: Galaxies in Gaussian groups consistently show higher star-forming and disc fractions compared to non-Gaussian groups.
Group dynamics seem to have a minimal impact on star-forming and disc fractions at large radii.
Galaxies in non-Gaussian groups have significantly lower disc fractions compared to field galaxies.
Infalling galaxies exhibit identical star-forming and disc fractions compared to field galaxies.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 4 reveal about the pre-processing of galaxies infalling onto groups with different halo masses?
choices: Pre-processing is equally effective for both low-mass and high-mass galaxies.
Low-mass galaxies infalling onto high-mass haloes experience the most significant pre-processing.
Pre-processing exclusively affects the star formation of infalling galaxies, leaving morphology unchanged.
The halo mass has no discernible impact on the pre-processing of infalling galaxies.
